course.subject: MGMT
course.name: Judgement and Decision Making in Organizations
course.description: This course is about how people make decisions, with special emphasis on decision making in an organizational context. It attempts to provide an understanding of employee and manager decision making at two levels - the individual and the group.

reviews.author: wym
reviews.title: Good grade with very light workload
reviews.comment_content: The course content is quite interesting as it describes a lot of experiments and traps that people encounter when making every day decisions. It feels like a psychology course instead of a management course to be honest.
reviews.comment_teaching: Carmen's teaching is quite lively and she gives a lot of real-life examples of the concepts taught in class. She is also very willing to answer questions and give you advice on your assignment if you consult her.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is split into a few components, midterm, finals, one group project, one decision analysis assignment and class participation. For decision analysis assignment, it is highly recommended to consult Carmen since she would be able to give you constructive advice before actually marking them. For all components, as long as you score slightly above mean, you'll be in A range.  
I got an A+ in the end.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is very light since you only have one presentation on an assigned reading at the end of the semester. There is only one assignment which is a Decision Analysis Assignment in the entire semester. Revisions do not require a long time as you can bring along cheatsheets in midterms and finals.

reviews.author: tingtingo_O
reviews.title: Very good grade with very light workload
reviews.comment_content:
The course is organized into 4 parts as follow:
Part 1 – Decision Analysis
1.1 Defining Your Decision Problems
1.2 Decisions Involving Multiple Objectives
1.3 Decision Making under Uncertainty
1.4 Collecting Information to Aid Decision Making

Part 2 – Heuristics and Biases:
2.1 Two Systems of Thinking
2.2 Availability Heuristics
2.3 Representativeness Heuristic
2.4 Anchoring and Adjustment
2.5: Embodied Cognition
2.6: Bounded Awareness

Part 3 – Choice and Preference:
3.1 Prospect Theory
3.2 Escalation of Commitment
3.3 Time and Preferences
3.4 Is More Choice Always Better?

Part 4 – Applications (Project Presentation):
4.1 Performance Appraisal
4.2 Motivating Employees by Money? Or…?
4.3 Unethical Decision Making
4.4 Going Green
reviews.comment_teaching: The lectures are interactive with occasionally some in-class group activities. Karman is also very friendly in giving you advice on your decision analysis assignment. She also explains the concepts clearly with real-life examples given.
reviews.comment_grading:
Extremely good grade.

Grade Components:
Participation: 5%
Mid Term Exam: 25%
Decision analysis assignment: 25%
Team project presentation: 25%
Total: 80% (This semester)

Statistics:
Participation: Full
Mid Term: 38/41 (Mean: 31.6, SD: 4.62)
Decision Analysis Assignment: 84/100 (Mean: 77.8, SD: 6.4)
Project: 85/100 (Mean: 84.9, SD: 5.2)

Grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
The least workload 4 credit course that I have ever taken in UST. The midterm allows you to bring one A4 sized cheat sheet (double-sided) while the topics covered is just half of the syllabus. You can just copy and paste the notes into the sheet.

The project doesn't require a report as well. Just reading an article and prepare a presentation for that article would be required.

The decision analysis assignment workload is also manageable as plenty of time will be given to you to work on that 1000 words essay.

reviews.author: lonelyguy
reviews.title: 靚grade到喊出嚟
reviews.comment_content:
Content is easy to understand and very interesting. You can use the skills in daily life to make a correct and rational judgement as well. Very practical!

The course is organized into 4 parts as follow:
Part 1 – Decision Analysis
1.1 Defining Your Decision Problems
1.2 Decisions Involving Multiple Objectives
1.3 Decision Making under Uncertainty
1.4 Collecting Information to Aid Decision Making

Part 2 – Heuristics and Biases:
2.1 Two Systems of Thinking
2.2 Availability Heuristics
2.3 Representativeness Heuristic
2.4 Anchoring and Adjustment
2.5: Embodied Cognition
2.6: Bounded Awareness

Part 3 – Choice and Preference:
3.1 Prospect Theory
3.2 Escalation of Commitment
3.3 Time and Preferences
3.4 Is More Choice Always Better?

Part 4 – Applications (Project Presentation):
4.1 Performance Appraisal
4.2 Motivating Employees by Money? Or…?
4.3 Unethical Decision Making
4.4 Going Green
reviews.comment_teaching:
Carmen is super nice, friendly and funny. She is a local professor, so you can use Cantonese to talk to her. She teaches very well and explains things very detailed. She may have a Hong Kong accent when speaks English. She makes the classroom atmosphere very chill and relaxing. You won't feel pressured in her class. Just enjoy and have fun in the class!

She also has some group activities, such as experiments. She once did an experiment of counting the number of M&M in a big jar. After the experiment, she gave all of us a bag of M&M chocolate as a small gift! You will not feel bored and she sometimes will end the lessons early.
reviews.comment_grading:
Extremely lenient grading. However, the final exam was cancelled, so you could not screw any of the grading components to secure an A range, especially the midterm exam.

Statistics:
5% Participation: 5/5 (highest)
25% Mid Term: 35/41 (Mean: 31.6, SD: 4.62)
25% Final: Cancelled
25% Assignment: 82/100 (Mean: 77.8, SD: 6.4)
25% Project: 85/100 (Mean: 84.9, SD: 5.2)

Grade: A

I did not score above 1 SD in any components and only scored mean in the project, but still managed to get an A. Super good grading!
reviews.comment_workload:
Very light workload. The lightest workload of a 4 credits course I have ever attended.

Attendance: She will take attendance every lesson. Just don't miss more than 6 lessons then your attendance score will be full.

Exam: You can bring an A4 size, a double-paged cheat sheet to the exam. Basically, you can just put everything in the cheat sheet and go to the exam directly if you do not have time to study.

Decision Analysis Assignment: I think this is the only workload of the course. It is quite difficult to think of a topic that is real and relevant to yourself. Consult Carmen to finish the assignment if you want to guarantee a good score. 1000 words limit.

Project: NO REPORT, you just need to do a 15 minutes presentation. Read an experiment and then stated the experiment result, procedures, with some business implications and suggestions on an organizational issue in your presentation.

reviews.author: Angelacharlotte
reviews.comment_content:
The course is divided into 4 modules:
A) Decision analysis
This part involves some calculations, not very difficult, but you have to understand the concepts.
B) Heuristics and Biases
C) Choices and preference
--> I think part B and C are very interesting and you can really learn some meaningful and inspiring things from the lectures.
D) Application (that's project presentations)
Listen to the other group's presentations and Carmen would prepare powerpoint for students to follow the presentations.

Plus, Carmen would prepare the powerpoint hard copies for us, so you don't have to print on your own :)
reviews.comment_teaching: I really enjoyed having Carmen's lessons, she often shared her personal experience when she was trying to explain some concepts, which made the concepts easy to understand and memorise. Also, she is a very friendly and funny professor, can always ask her if you have any questions!
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is very nice.
5 points: Participation (PRS in class)
25 points:  Midterm
25 points:  Individual assignment (based on Module A: Decision Analysis)
25 points: Project presentation: [60% Summarise and analyse the research article assigned + 30% recommendation came up by ourselves]
25 points: Final
reviews.comment_workload: Personally, I think the workload is fair for a 4-credit course, only 1 assignment and 1 project presentation. If you attend lessons, you will be able to perform well in the course. And the midterm and final are open book, so you don't have to memorise many things, you just need to spend some time to read and understand the powerpoints.

reviews.author: stephanie1234
reviews.comment_content: The content is about interesting mindsets and decision making concept, for example the mistakes and heuristics that people often made. I think generally it is similar to psychology and this course will explain a lot of psychological concepts and examples, experiments.
reviews.comment_teaching: Carmen is my girl god, she is smart, pretty, nice and friendly. She prepares a lot of things for the class, for example, she will provide the lecture notes for every class and always give us little snacks to encourage us.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is super good.
I thought I will get C+ because I'm in the mean range.
But end up I got a B, that surprises me.
Participation 5 points
Examination 1 25 points
Examination 2 25 points
Decision analysis assignment 25 points
Team project presentation 25 points
Total 105 points
midterm: 39/50 mean:40/50
Decision making assignment: 60/100
mean:70/100 (80 base-line)
Final: 38/45 mean 33.5/45
Team project:80/100 mean 79.2/100
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is light to me as it is a 4 credit course, it only consists of 25% midterm, 25% final, 1000 words essay (assignment) and a presentation (no report!)
Unfortunately my group is all filled with freeriders, so my workload in presentation is quite high...
All exams are open notes, the mean in the exams are not very high.

reviews.author: mmhleung
reviews.comment_content: Fun course and interesting topics on how we make decisions and biases that affect our decision making processes. The first section of the course involves simple probability and decision trees, the second section comprises of the various biases and heuristics, and the final sections is made of various topics taught by the students through group projects.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor tries to make the topics as interesting as possible and succeeds in doing so. Class environment is relaxed, and the powerpoints make it very easy to follow what the professor is teaching.
reviews.comment_grading: The projects and exams are fairly easy; however, most students tend to do very well and it is harder to beat the curve. It is the little things that can make the biggest difference (such as attending every class).
reviews.comment_workload: Two exams, a midterm and a final. Both consist of mostly multiple choice and a couple of short answer questions. Mid-term assignment is a decision analysis problem (no more than 2-3 pages) based on the first section of the course. Final project is done with a group, which greatly lessens individual workload.

reviews.author: Andy Han
reviews.comment_content: interesting content, tells you how to negotiate in daily life. He tough us how to always be a winner in a negotiation---- find your bottom line, at the same time, he told us some important term in the negotiation like BATNA and trading. Compare to other BBA course, this course teach something that is useful in the future.
reviews.comment_teaching: Highly interactive course. The professor really has a sense of humour.
reviews.comment_workload: The work load is not large. Except for the final essay, you only need to read the case materials related to next negotiation. It only takes half an hour to do so
